preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: This is technical reference documentation for the DocBook XSL Stylesheets; it documents (some of) the parameters, templates, and other elements of the stylesheets.

This reference describes each of the HTML Stylesheet parameters. These are the easily customizable parts of the stylesheet. If you want to specify an alternate value for one or more of these parameters, you can do so in a driver stylesheet.
For example, if you want to change the html.stylesheet to reference.css, you might create a driver stylesheet like this:
Naturally, you have to change the href attribute on <xsl:import> to point to docbook.xsl on your system. (Or chunk.xsl, if you're using chunking.)
This is not intended to be user documentation. It is provided for developers writing customization layers for the stylesheets, and for anyone who's interested in how it works.
Although I am trying to be thorough, this documentation is known to be incomplete. Don't forget to read the source, too :-)

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), admonitions are presented in an alternate style that uses a graphic. Default graphics are provided in the distribution.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Indicates what column callouts appear in by default

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If a callout does not identify a column (for example, if it uses the linerange unit), it will appear in the default column.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Use graphics for callouts?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, callouts are presented with graphics (e.g., reverse-video circled numbers instead of "(1)", "(2)", etc.). Default graphics are provided in the distribution.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Extension for callout graphics

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Sets the extension to use on callout graphics.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of the largest callout graphic

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If callout.graphics is non-zero, graphics are used to represent callout numbers. The value of callout.graphics.number.limit is the largest number for which a graphic exists. If the callout number exceeds this limit, the default presentation "(nnn)" will always be used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Path to callout graphics

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Sets the path, probably relative to the directory where the HTML files are created, to the callout graphics.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Use Unicode characters rather than images for callouts.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The stylesheets can use either an image of the numbers one to ten, or the single Unicode character which represents the numeral, in white on a black background. Use this to select the Unicode character option.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specify a font for Unicode glyphs

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The name of the font to specify around Unicode callout glyphs. If set to the empty string, no font change will occur.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of the largest callout graphic

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If callout.graphics is non-zero, graphics are used to represent callout numbers. The value of callout.graphics.number.limit is the largest number for which a graphic exists. If the callout number exceeds this limit, the default presentation "(nnn)" will always be used.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Specifies, in points, the distance by which each level of the TOC is indented from its parent.

This value is expressed in points, without a unit (in other words, it is a bare number). Using a bare number allows the stylesheet to perform calculations that would otherwise have to be performed by the FO processor because not all processors support expressions.

refsect1.title: Description

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable PassiveTeX extensions?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, PassiveTeX extensions will be used. At present, this consists of PDF bookmarks and sorted index terms.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If you want type math directly in TeX notation in equations, this parameter specifies notation used. Currently are supported two values -- plain and latex. Empty value means that you are not using TeX math at all.
Preferred way for including TeX alternative of math is inside of textobject element. Eg.:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable XEP extensions?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, XEP extensions will be used. XEP extensions consists of PDF bookmarks and document information.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Indicate which lines should be numbered

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If line numbering is enabled, everyNth line will be numbered.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable the line numbering extension

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, verbatim environments (elements that have the format='linespecific' notation attribute: address, literallayout, programlisting, screen, synopsis) that specify line numbering will have, surprise, line numbers.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specify a separator between line numbers and lines

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The separator is inserted between line numbers and lines in the verbatim environment.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Indicates the width of line numbers

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If line numbering is enabled, line numbers will appear right justified in a field "width" characters wide.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable the table columns extension function

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The table columns extension function adjusts the widths of table columns in the HTML result to more accurately reflect the specifications in the CALS table.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable the textinsert extension element

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The textinsert extension element inserts the contents of a a file into the result tree (as text).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable extensions

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, extensions may be used. Each extension is further controlled by its own parameter. But if use.extensions is zero, no extensions will be used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are Appendixes automatically enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled appendixes will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are chapters automatically enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled chapters will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are parts and references enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled parts and references will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are prefaces enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled prefaces will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are sections enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled sections will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Do section labels include the component label?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), section labels are prefixed with the label of the component that contains them.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Renumber chapters in each part?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If label.from.part is non-zero, components (chapters, appendixes, etc.) will be numbered from 1 in each part. Otherwise, they will be numbered monotonically throughout each book.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specify the root element to format

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If rootid is specified, it must be the value of an ID that occurs in the document being formatted. The entire document will be loaded and parsed, but formatting will begin at the element identified, rather than at the root. For example, this allows you to process only chapter 4 of a book.
Because the entire document is available to the processor, automatic numbering, cross references, and other dependencies are correctly resolved.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print single-year ranges (e.g., 1998-1999)

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, year ranges that span a single year will be printed in range notation (1998-1999) instead of discrete notation (1998, 1999).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Collate copyright years into ranges?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, copyright years will be collated into ranges.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Is othername in author a middle name?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), the othername of an author appears between the firstname and surname. Otherwise, othername is suppressed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Decorate elements of a FuncSynopsis?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), elements of the FuncSynopsis will be decorated (e.g. bold or italic). The decoration is controlled by functions that can be redefined in a customization layer.

refnamediv.refpurpose: What style of 'FuncSynopsis' should be generated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If funcsynopsis.style is ansi, ANSI-style function synopses are generated for a funcsynopsis, otherwise K&R-style function synopses are generated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generate parens after a function?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If not 0, the formatting of a function element will include generated parenthesis.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Output NAME header before 'RefName'(s)?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), a "NAME" section title is output before the list of 'RefName's. This parameter and refentry.generate.title are mutually exclusive.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Output title before 'RefName'(s)?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), the reference page title or first name is output before the list of 'RefName's. This parameter and refentry.generate.name are mutually exclusive.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Output manvolnum as part of refentry cross-reference?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: if true (non-zero), the manvolnum is used when cross-referencing refentrys, either with xref or citerefentry.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The default width of tables

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If specified, this value will be used for the WIDTH attribute on tables that do not specify an alternate width (with the dbhtml processing instruction).

refnamediv.refpurpose: The (absolute) nominal width of tables

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: In order to convert CALS column widths into HTML column widths, it is sometimes necessary to have an absolute table width to use for conversion of mixed absolute and relative widths. This value must be an absolute length (not a percentag).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Text to separate bibliography entries

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Text to separate bibliography entries

refnamediv.refpurpose: Name of the bibliography collection file

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Maintaining bibliography entries across a set of documents is tedious, time consuming, and error prone. It makes much more sense, usually, to store all of the bibliography entries in a single place and simply extract the ones you need in each document.
That's the purpose of the bibliography.collection parameter. To setup a global bibliography database, follow these steps:

First, create a stand-alone bibliography document that contains all of the documents that you wish to reference. Make sure that each bibliography entry (whether you use biblioentry or bibliomixed) has an ID.
My global bibliography, ~/bibliography.xml begins like this:

informalexample.programlisting:
<!DOCTYPE bibliography PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DocBook XML V4.1.2//EN" "http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.1.2/docbookx.dtd"> <bibliography><title>References</title>
<bibliomixed id="xml-rec"><abbrev>XML 1.0</abbrev>Tim Bray, Jean Paoli, C. M. Sperberg-McQueen, and Eve Maler, editors. <citetitle><ulink url="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml">Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.0 Second Edition</ulink></citetitle>. World Wide Web Consortium, 2000. </bibliomixed>
<bibliomixed id="xml-names"><abbrev>Namespaces</abbrev>Tim Bray, Dave Hollander, and Andrew Layman, editors. <citetitle><ulink url="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml-names/">Namespaces in XML</ulink></citetitle>. World Wide Web Consortium, 1999. </bibliomixed>
<!-- ... --> </bibliography>

refsect1.para: When you create a bibliography in your document, simply provide empty bibliomixed entries for each document that you wish to cite. Make sure that these elements have the same ID as the corresponding real entry in your global bibliography.
For example:

informalexample.programlisting:
<bibliography><title>Bibliography</title>
<bibliomixed id="xml-rec"/> <bibliomixed id="xml-names"/> <bibliomixed id="DKnuth86">Donald E. Knuth. <citetitle>Computers and Typesetting: Volume B, TeX: The Program</citetitle>. Addison-Wesley, 1986. ISBN 0-201-13437-3. </bibliomixed> <bibliomixed id="relaxng"/>
</bibliography>

refsect1.para: Note that it's perfectly acceptable to mix entries from your global bibliography with normal entries. You can use xref or other elements to cross-reference your bibliography entries in exactly the same way you do now.

Finally, when you are ready to format your document, simply set the bibliography.collection parameter (in either a customization layer or directly through your processor's interface) to point to your global bibliography.
The stylesheets will format the bibliography in your document as if all of the entries referenced appeared there literally.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generate links from glossterm to glossentry automaticaly?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, a link will be automatically created from glossterm to glossentry for that glossary term. This is usefull when your glossterm names are consistent and you don't want to add links manually.
If there is linkend on glossterm then is used instead of autogeneration of link.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Does automatic glossterm linking only apply to firstterms?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, only firstterms will be automatically linked to the glossary. If glossary linking is not enabled, this parameter has no effect.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Name of the glossary collection file

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Glossaries maintained independently across a set of documents are likely to become inconsistent unless considerable effort is expended to keep them in sync. It makes much more sense, usually, to store all of the glossary entries in a single place and simply extract the ones you need in each document.
That's the purpose of the glossary.collection parameter. To setup a global glossary database, follow these steps:

refsect2.title: Setting Up the Glossary Database
refsect2.para: First, create a stand-alone glossary document that contains all of the entries that you wish to reference. Make sure that each glossary entry has an ID.

informalexample.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <!DOCTYPE glossary PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DocBook XML V4.1.2//EN" "http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.1.2/docbookx.dtd"> <glossary> <glossaryinfo> <editor><firstname>Eric</firstname><surname>Raymond</surname></editor> <title>Jargon File 4.2.3 (abridged)</title> <releaseinfo>Just some test data</releaseinfo> </glossaryinfo>
<glossdiv><title>0</title>
<glossentry> <glossterm>0</glossterm> <glossdef> <para>Numeric zero, as opposed to the letter `O' (the 15th letter of the English alphabet). In their unmodified forms they look a lot alike, and various kluges invented to make them visually distinct have compounded the confusion. If your zero is center-dotted and letter-O is not, or if letter-O looks almost rectangular but zero looks more like an American football stood on end (or the reverse), you're probably looking at a modern character display (though the dotted zero seems to have originated as an option on IBM 3270 controllers). If your zero is slashed but letter-O is not, you're probably looking at an old-style ASCII graphic set descended from the default typewheel on the venerable ASR-33 Teletype (Scandinavians, for whom /O is a letter, curse this arrangement). (Interestingly, the slashed zero long predates computers; Florian Cajori's monumental "A History of Mathematical Notations" notes that it was used in the twelfth and thirteenth centuries.) If letter-O has a slash across it and the zero does not, your display is tuned for a very old convention used at IBM and a few other early mainframe makers (Scandinavians curse <emphasis>this</emphasis> arrangement even more, because it means two of their letters collide). Some Burroughs/Unisys equipment displays a zero with a <emphasis>reversed</emphasis> slash. Old CDC computers rendered letter O as an unbroken oval and 0 as an oval broken at upper right and lower left. And yet another convention common on early line printers left zero unornamented but added a tail or hook to the letter-O so that it resembled an inverted Q or cursive capital letter-O (this was endorsed by a draft ANSI standard for how to draw ASCII characters, but the final standard changed the distinguisher to a tick-mark in the upper-left corner). Are we sufficiently confused yet?</para> </glossdef> </glossentry>
<glossentry> <glossterm>1TBS</glossterm> <glossdef> <para role="accidence"> <phrase role="pronounce"></phrase> <phrase role="partsofspeach">n</phrase> </para> <para>The "One True Brace Style"</para> <glossseealso>indent style</glossseealso> </glossdef> </glossentry>
<!-- ... -->
</glossdiv>
<!-- ... -->
</glossary>

refsect2.title: Marking Up Glossary Terms
refsect2.para: That takes care of the glossary database, now you have to get the entries into your document. Unlike bibliography entries, which can be empty, creating placeholder glossary entries would be very tedious. So instead, support for glossary.collection relies on implicit linking.

In your source document, simply use firstterm and glossterm to identify the terms you wish to have included in the glossary. The stylesheets assume that you will either set the baseform attribute correctly, or that the content of the element exactly matches a term in your glossary.
If you're using a glossary.collection, don't make explicit links on the terms in your document.
So, in your document, you might write things like this:

informalexample.programlisting: <para>This is dummy text, without any real meaning. The point is simply to reference glossary terms like <glossterm>0</glossterm> and the <firstterm baseform="1TBS">One True Brace Style (1TBS)</firstterm>. The <glossterm>1TBS</glossterm>, as you can probably imagine, is a nearly religious issue.</para>

refsect2.para: If you set the firstterm.only.link parameter, only the terms marked with firstterm will be links. Otherwise, all the terms will be linked.

refsect2.title: Marking Up the Glossary
refsect2.para: The glossary itself has to be identified for the stylesheets. For lack of a better choice, the role is used. To identify the glossary as the target for automatic processing, set the role to auto. The title of this glossary (and any other information from the glossaryinfo that's rendered by your stylesheet) will be displayed, but the entries will come from the database.
Unfortunately, the glossary can't be empty, so you must put in at least one glossentry. The content of this entry is irrelevant, it will not be rendered:

informalexample.programlisting: <glossary role="auto"> <glossentry> <glossterm>Irrelevant</glossterm> <glossdef> <para>If you can see this, the document was processed incorrectly. Use the <parameter>glossary.collection</parameter> parameter.</para> </glossdef> </glossentry> </glossary>

refsect2.para: What about glossary divisions? If your glossary database has glossary divisions and your automatic glossary contains at least one glossdiv, the automic glossary will have divisions. If the glossdiv is missing from either location, no divisions will be rendered.
Glossary entries (and divisions, if appropriate) in the glossary will occur in precisely the order they occur in your database.

refsect2.title: Formatting the Document
refsect2.para: Finally, when you are ready to format your document, simply set the glossary.collection parameter (in either a customization layer or directly through your processor's interface) to point to your global glossary.
The stylesheets will format the glossary in your document as if all of the entries implicilty referenced appeared there literally.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Display comment elements?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), comments will be displayed, otherwise they are suppressed. Comments here refers to the comment element, which will be renamed remark in DocBook V4.0, not XML comments (<-- like this -->) which are unavailable.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Punctuation after an honorific in a personal name.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This parameter specifies the punctuation that should be added after an honorific in a personal name.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Format segmented lists as tables?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, segmentedlists will be formatted as tables.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Format variablelists lists as blocks?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, variablelists will be formatted as blocks.
If you have long terms, proper list markup in the FO case may produce unattractive lists. By setting this parameter, you can force the stylesheets to produce block markup instead of proper lists.

refnamediv.refpurpose: To set the style for block quotations.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The blockquote.properties attribute set specifies the formating properties of block quotations.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Display URLs after ulinks?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, the URL of each ULink will appear after the text of the link. If the text of the link and the URL are identical, the URL is suppressed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generate footnotes for ULinks?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, the URL of each ULink will appear as a footnote. Not yet implemented!

refnamediv.refpurpose: Allow URLs to be automatically hyphenated

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If not empty, the specified character (or more generally, content) is added to URLs after every /. If the character specified is a Unicode soft hyphen (0x00AD) or Unicode zero-width space (0x200B), some FO processors will be able to reasonably hyphenate long URLs.
As of 28 Jan 2002, discretionary hyphens are more widely and correctly supported than zero-width spaces for this purpose.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Identifies the output format of this stylesheet

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The Saxon extension functions need to know if the output format is HTML ('html') or XSL Formatting Objects ('fo'). This variable answers that question. Valid settings are 'html' or 'fo'.

section.title: Understanding XSL FO Margins
section.para: In order for the parameters in this section to make sense, it is useful to consider .

textobject.para: This figure shows the physical page with the various FO page regions identified.

section.para: First, let's consider the regions on the page.
The white region is the physical page. Its dimensions are determined by the page.height and page.width parameters.
The yellow region is the region-body. The size and placement of the region body is constrained by the dimensions labelled in the figure.

The pink region at the top of the page is the region-before. The darker area inside the region-before is the header text. In XSL, the default display alignment for the region-before is before, but the DocBook stylesheets explicitly make it after. That's why the darker area is at the bottom.

The pink region at the bottom of the page is the region-after. The darker area is the footer text. In XSL, the default display alignment for the region-after is before (really!), but the DocBook stylesheets explicitly make it after. That's why the darker area is at the bottom.
The dimensions in the figure are:

listitem.para: The sum of the page-master margin-left and the region-body margin-left. In DocBook, the region-body margin-left is zero by default, so this is simply the page-master region-left.
The sum of the page-master margin-right and the region-body margin-right. In DocBook, the region-body margin-right is zero by default, so this is simply the page-master region-left.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The bottom margin of the page

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The bottom page margin is the distance from the bottom of the region-after to the physical bottom of the page.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The inner page margin

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The inner page margin is the distance from binding edge of the page to the first column of text. In the left-to-right, top-to-bottom writing direction, this is the left margin of recto pages.
The inner and outer margins are usually the same unless the output is double-sided.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The outer page margin

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The outer page margin is the distance from non-binding edge of the page to the last column of text. In the left-to-right, top-to-bottom writing direction, this is the right margin of recto pages.
The inner and outer margins are usually the same unless the output is double-sided.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The top margin of the page

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The top page margin is the distance from the physical top of the page to the top of the region-before.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Select the page orientation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: In portrait orientation, the short edge is horizontal; in landscape orientation, it is vertical.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Select the paper type

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The paper type is a convenient way to specify the paper size. The list of known paper sizes includes USletter and most of the A, B, and C sizes. See page.width.portrait, for example.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Is the document to be printed double sided?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Double-sided documents are printed with a slightly wider margin on the binding edge of the page.
FIXME: The current set of parameters does not take writing direction into account.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The bottom margin of the body text

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The body bottom margin is the distance from the last line of text in the page body to the bottom of the region-after.

refnamediv.refpurpose: To specify the size of the top margin of a page

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The body top margin is the distance from the top of the region-before to the first line of text in the page body.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specify the default text alignment

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The default text alignment is used for most body text.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specify hyphenation behavior

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, words may be hyphenated. Otherwise, they may not.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specify the line-height property

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Sets the line-height property.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specifies the number of columns of text on the page

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The specified number of columns of text will appear on each page.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of columns in the index

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This parameter specifies the number of columns on pages in the index. The default is the same as the column.count.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specifies the height of the footer.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The region after extent is the height of the area where footers are printed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specifies the height of the header

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The region before extent is the height of the area where headers are printed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Default units for an unqualified dimension

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If an unqualified dimension is encountered (for example, in a graphic width), the default-units will be used for the units. Unqualified dimensions are not allowed in XSL Formatting Objects.

refnamediv.refpurpose: What space do you want between normal paragraphs

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Specify the spacing required between normal paragraphs

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specifies the default point size for body text

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The body font size is specified in two parameters (body.font.master and body.font.size) so that math can be performed on the font size by XSLT.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specifies the default font size for body text

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The body font size is specified in two parameters (body.font.master and body.font.size) so that math can be performed on the font size by XSLT.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The font size for footnotes

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The footnote font size is used for...footnotes!

refnamediv.refpurpose: Adjust the left margin for titles

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This parameter adjusts the left margin for titles.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The URI of the image to be used for draft watermarks

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The image to be used for draft watermarks.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The default font family for body text

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The body font family is the default font used for text in the page body.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The font family for copyright, quotes, and other symbols

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The dingbat font family is used for dingbats. If it is defined as the empty string, no font change is effected around dingbats.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The default font family for monospace environments

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The monospace font family is used for verbatim environments (program listings, screens, etc.).

refnamediv.refpurpose: The default sans-serif font family

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The default sans-serif font family. At the present, this isn't actually used by the stylesheets.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The default font family for titles

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The title font family is used for titles (chapter, section, figure, etc.)

refnamediv.refpurpose: What spacing do you want before lists?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Specify the spacing required before a list.

refnamediv.refpurpose: What space do you want between list items?

refsect1.para: Specify what spacing you want between each list item.
